column2: '''South Tryon Square''' is a development consisting of two 14-story [[Tower block|high-rise]]s in [[Charlotte, North Carolina]]. The first building, at 201 South Tryon, was opened in 1961 as the American Credit Corporation building; from its second renovation, in 1999, the facade was changed to the current gray and green [[granite]] with green glass and ornamental metal.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://skyscraperpage.com/cities/?cityID=536|title=Charlotte|publisher=skyscraperpage.com|accessdate=2009-03-26}}</ref><ref name=cmhpf>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmhpf.org/educationarchitecturept2.htm|title=Charlotte Architecture: Design Through Time Part 2|first=Dr. Thomas W.|last=Hanchett|publisher=Charlotte-Mecklenburg Historic Landmarks Commission|accessdate=2009-03-26}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ppmglobal-properties.com/10/SouthTryonSquareHome.html|title=201 South Tryon|accessdate=2012-04-10}}</ref> The second building, at 237 South Tryon, was opened in 2001 as a hotel branded [[Courtyard by Marriott]] and houses the 698-space [[Multistorey car park|parking garage]].<ref name=237STryon/> Both buildings are also connected to the neighboring [[BB&T Center]] by dual [[Skyway|skybridge]]s, as part of the [[Overstreet Mall]].
column4:
201 South Tryon Street
[[Charlotte, North Carolina]], United States

column2: '''Winthrow-Melhase Block''', also known as '''Stevens Hotel''', was built in 1906 in [[Klamath Falls, Oregon]].  It was listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]] in 1982.<ref name=nris/> The building was severely damaged by the [[1993 Klamath Falls earthquakes]], and was subsequently demolished.

column2: '''Aztec Hotel''' is a historical landmark building in [[Monrovia, California|Monrovia]], in the [[San Gabriel Valley]], [[California]]. The hotel is an example of [[Mayan Revival architecture]] still in existence. It was designed by architect [[Robert Stacy-Judd]], and built on [[U.S. Route 66 in California|U.S. Route 66]] in 1925-26.<ref name=\PCAD - Aztec Hotel
column6: CA|url=http://pcad.lib.washington.edu/building/1778/|access-date=2020-06-10|website=pcad.lib.washington.edu}}</ref> The hotel opened to the public in September 1925
column7: and contained over 40 rooms.<ref name=\":0\">{{Cite web|last=Time|first=San Gabriel Valley in|title=Aztec Hotel in Monrovia

column2: '''Clinton Hotel Miami Beach''' or '''The New Clinton Hotel And Spa''' is an [[Art Deco]] [[hotel]] located in [[Miami Beach, Florida|Miami Beach]], [[Florida]].

column5: this 147-room luxury boutique hotel has over {{convert|5000|sqft|m2}} of meeting and event space as well as a full-service restaurant.<ref>[http://www.printworksbistro.com \"Print Works Bistro\"]</ref> The hotel utilized more than 70 sustainable practices during construction and is a model for green hotel construction."
